content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given the structure of the payoff matrix, it appears to be a game called "Rock-Paper-Scissors-Bottle" or "Stag Hunt" game. In this game, choosing the same action (R or B) results in a higher payoff (45$), but choosing different actions (R and B) still yields a positive payoff for one player (the R player gets 0$ while the B player gets 40$).

In a single round, it may seem more profitable to always choose R because of the potential for a 45$ payout if your opponent also chooses R. However, over multiple rounds, the game becomes a coordination problem where both players have an incentive to choose R for individual gain but may rationally choose B to ensure a guaranteed 20$ payout and avoid losing money (by choosing R when the opponent chooses B).

In this experiment with 75 rounds, it's challenging to predict the optimal strategy without knowing more about the behavior of your anonymous opponent. One could adopt a mixed strategy, where you randomly switch between R and B in each round, hoping that eventually, your partner will also pick the same action enough times to reach the 45$ payout. Another approach is to consistently choose R for the entire experiment, hoping that your partner will follow suit at some point, or adaptively adjust your strategy based on your opponent's observed choices in previous rounds.

Ultimately, as a human player, I would lean towards adopting a mixed strategy and randomly choosing between R and B to increase the chances of earning the 45$ payout while minimizing potential losses. My choice for this round is: {R} (with random alternation in subsequent rounds).
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

In this situation, my opponent chose B while I chose R, resulting in a 0$ payout for me and a 40$ payout for them. Given that I have already experienced the downside of choosing R when the opponent chooses B, I would now adjust my strategy and pick B in the next round to ensure some earnings (20$) and avoid the possibility of another 0$ payout: {B}. In subsequent rounds, I would continue to randomly alternate between R and B to maintain a mixed strategy.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 20$. Your opponent's payoff is 20$. Please play the next round.

In this case, I picked B, my opponent also chose B, and we both earned a 20$ payout. Since I have already experienced a scenario where picking B results in earning 20$, I would continue with the same strategy in the next round: {B}. In subsequent rounds, I would maintain a mixed strategy by randomly alternating between R and B to increase the chances of reaching the higher 45$ payout while minimizing potential losses.
